abstract: The Serious Fraud Office of Britain cautioned that it first needed to make sure that its use of an Autonomy product did not pose a conflict of interest for an investigation into its sale to Hewlett-Packard.
snippet: The Serious Fraud Office of Britain cautioned that it first needed to make sure that its use of an Autonomy product did not pose a conflict of interest for an investigation into its sale to Hewlett-Packard.
lead_paragraph: Presumably, the antitrust investigators who looked at Microsoft back in the day had Windows software on their own computers. One could imagine that the prosecutors who brought accounting fraud cases against WorldCom executives might have used its MCI long-distance service. And any number of regulators around the world are likely to have used Google for personal and professional reasons.

headline.main: One Possible Hitch to an Autonomy Investigation

abstract: In agreeing to settle a case brought by 38 states over the Street View mapping project, the company for the first time is required to aggressively police its own workers on privacy issues.
snippet: In agreeing to settle a case brought by 38 states over the Street View mapping project, the company for the first time is required to aggressively police its own workers on privacy issues.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Google on Tuesday acknowledged to state officials that it had violated people’s privacy during its Street View mapping project when it casually scooped up passwords, e-mail and other personal information from unsuspecting computer users.

headline.main: Google Concedes That Drive-By Prying Violated Privacy
headline.print_headline: Google Concedes Drive-by Prying Violated Privacy

abstract: The government called for a law requiring Internet service providers to give all traffic on their networks equal priority, saying existing rules were insufficient.
snippet: The government called for a law requiring Internet service providers to give all traffic on their networks equal priority, saying existing rules were insufficient.
lead_paragraph: SERRAVAL, France — The French government on Tuesday called for a law requiring Internet service providers to give all the traffic on their networks equal priority, saying existing rules were insufficient for protecting free speech online and ensuring fair competition among Web publishers.

headline.main: France Proposes New Rules for Internet Equal Access
headline.print_headline: France Proposes New Rules to Guarantee Equal Access to the Internet

byline.original: By Eric Pfanner and Nicola Clark
